assessments.task_description:
Active contribution to class discussions.

Active participation in the seminar sessions is essential for the course. Just as presenters will be expected to lead group discussion, audience members will b expected to engage with the speaker and discuss the material being presented in a thoughtful and constructive manner. Your participation is each session will be assessed on a pass/fail basis based on the quality (not quantity) of your contribution.

Assessment Criteria:

Demonstrates deep engagement with course materials.

Asks insightful questions and contributes to discussions.

Engages respectfully and thoughtfully with peers.


If you are unable to participate actively during the session for whatever reason, please discuss with me ahead of time.

assessments.task_description: To encourage active in-session participation, you will be required to submit a brief reflection on each of the readings being covered in that week's session, prior to the session. The reflection should detail questions and/or comments that arose during your reading of the material (and can make for useful contributions to the in-session discussion). There is no word limit for the reflections, but they are expected to be brief (approximately 150-200 words per paper). Reading reflections are an excellent avenue for seeking clarification about any of the materials covered in the seminar. Reflections are individually graded as pass/fail.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Reading reflections are to be submitted via email to the course coordinator prior to the seminar each week.

assessments.task_description:
Each student will deliver a 20 minute oral presentation on a selected topic from the course, followed by a 10 minute Q&A session.

Students may choose from the list of pre-approved publications or propose their own (subject to approval).

 

Assessment Criteria:

Clear and engaging presentation of research paper with little or no reliance on written notes.

Ability to explain neuroscience concepts in an accessible way.

Strong understanding of the quality of scientific evidence. 

Can identify the constraints that limit scientific inferences. 


More detail on giving a strong presentation will be given in class.

assessments.task_description:
You are required to submit a 2000 (+/- 200 words) essay on one of the real world problem themes (not the one you presented a seminar on). Your essay must be based on three papers provided in the specific theme. You should review each of the three papers in detail. There should be no more than five or six papers in your reference list.

How has the research informed us about the real world problem they address? What does the balance of evidence in your three papers say about a possible solution or theory? 

More detail on writing a strong essay will be provided in class.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submitted via Turnitin. Please retain a copy of your submission.

learning_activities.topic:
Introduction to Course - 1

Topics:

·                    What is social neuroscience?

·                    Evolutionary and comparative perspectives on social cognition

·                    Overview of key brain structures (amygdala, prefrontal cortex, mirror neuron system)

Readings:

Adolphs (2009), The Social Brain: Neural Basis of Social Knowledge

Annu Rev Psychol. 2009 ; 60: 693–716. doi:10.1146/annurev.psych.60.110707.163514.

Lieberman, M. D. (2007). Social cognitive neuroscience: A review of core processes. Annual Review of Psychology, 58, 259–289.

learning_activities.topic:
Introduction to Course - 2

Topics:

·                    Face perception & the fusiform face area (FFA)

·                    The superior temporal sulcus (STS) and biological motion

·                    Emotional expression and amygdala involvement

Reading:

Kanwisher, N., & Yovel, G. (2006). The fusiform face area: A cortical region specialized for face perception. Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B, 361, 2109–2128.

 

Potential Student Seminar Readings:

Wardle, S. G., Taubert, J., Teichmann, L., & Baker, C. I. (2020). Rapid and dynamic processing of face pareidolia in the human brain. Nature communications, 11(1), 4518.

McMahon, E., Bonner, M. F., & Isik, L. (2024). Hierarchical organization of social action features along the lateral visual pathway. Current biology, 34(4), 931–933.

learning_activities.topic:
Student Preparation (No Class)

Topics:

·                    Role of the amygdala in emotional processing

·                    Implicit bias and social evaluation

·                    The amygdala’s role in recognizing trustworthiness

Reading:

Phelps, E. A., et al. (2000). Performance on indirect measures of race evaluation predicts amygdala activation. Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience, 12(5), 729–738.

 

Potential Student Seminar Readings:

Taubert, J., Wardle, S. G., Patterson, A., & Baker, C. I. (2024). Beyond faces: the contribution of the amygdala to visual processing in the macaque brain. Cerebral cortex, 34(6), bhae245.

Lin, T., Pehlivanoglu, D., Ziaei, M., Liu, P., Woods, A. J., Feifel, D., Fischer, H., & Ebner, N. C. (2022). Age-Related Differences in Amygdala Activation Associated With Face Trustworthiness but No Evidence of Oxytocin Modulation. Frontiers in psychology, 13, 838642.
